dc:description:
TRPM3 encodes a protein, transient receptor potential cation channel subfamily M member 3, which is temperature- and neurosteroid-sensitive. The first study by Bennett et al in 2014 (PMID: 25090642). reported TRPM3 in relationship to autosomal dominant cataract with or without high pressure glaucoma in a 5-generation Caucasian-American pedigree. Genome-wide linkage analysis mapped the cataract locus to the pericentric region of human chromosome 9, and exome sequencing of the linked region identified a heterozygous substitution of isoleucine-to-methionine at codon 65 (c.195A>G, p.Ile65Met) in TRPM3 transcript NM_001007471.2. This variant segregated fully with the cataract in the family. Functional studies of the human p.Ile65M knock-in mice model showed that heterozygous Trpm3-mutant mice developed cataract (2021, PMID: 33484482) and lens from the Trpm3-mutation mice displayed elevated cytosolic Ca2+ levels and an imbalance of sodium (Na+) and potassium (K+) ions, coupled with increased water content, suggesting failure of Trpm3-mutant lens to osmoregulation and gain-of-function as the disease mechanism (2024, PMID: 38334649).
The second study by Li et al in 2018 (PMID: 29914532) sequenced 80 cataract-associated genes for a cohort of 39 Chinese pediatric cataract cases and detected a heterozygous variant, c.3920G>C, p.Arg1307Thr in TRPM3 transcript NM_206944.4, in one family. This variant segregated with the cataract in the family. No data of functional study is available for this variant. 
As of this curation, only two above-mentioned variants in TRPM3 have been linked to inherited form of cataract in two families. As of the genetic evidence, the case level and segregation data were scored up to 3.6 points. The functional experimental data from the human p.Ile65Met knock-in mouse model was scored up to 3.25 points. Taking together 6.85 points is scored in total with moderate evidence to support the TRPM3-cataract relationship. While more evidence is needed to establish this relationship definitively, no contradictory evidence has merged. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Glaucoma and Neuro-Ophthalmology Gene Curation Expert Panel (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description:
knock-in mice with human p.Leu65Met develop cataract:
homozygous (Trpm3-M/M) mutant mice developed severe, progressive, anterior pyramid-like cataract with microphthalmia. homozygous cataract-related variant has not been reported.
heterozygous (Trpm3-I/M) and hemizygous (Trpm3-M/-) mutants developed anterior pyramidal cataract with delayed onset and progression. This mimics the cataracts associated with TRPM3 p.Leu65Met variants.

evidence.rdfs:label: 5-generation family

member.rdfs:label: III:16
member.detectionMethod: SNP genotyping and genome-wide linkage analysis on 24 members (19 affected and 5 unaffected) identified a new locus for cataract and glaucoma mapped to human chromosome 9; Microsatellite markers genotyping and linkage analysis on all 36 available family members to validate the SNP disease interval; Exome and target sequencing to identify the disease associated gene(s)

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: cataract and high-tension glaucoma with variable anterior segment defects

evidence.dc:description: Human TRPM3 p.Ile65Met mutation has been linked with inherited form of early-onset cataract with or without other eye abnormalities. The germline p.Ile65Met knock-in mice developed cataract: the homozygous knock-in mice developed severe, progressive, anterior pyramid-like cataract with microphthalmia, whereas, heterozygous knock-in mice developed anterior pyramidal cataract with delayed onset and progression -
evidence.rdfs:label: Generation of Trpm3-mutant mice by CRISPR/Cas9 gene-editing

evidence.dc:description: Collagen staining was also done on the FFPE section of nucleated eyes and showed that Trpm3-mutant lenses accumulate collagen fibrils within the anterior pyramidal cataract region of opacification.

evidence.rdfs:label: Histochemical staining FFPE section of nucleated eyes

evidence.dc:description: Tprm3 mutant lenses had elevated intracellular [Ca2+] coupled with increased [Na+], recused [K+], and increased water content compared to wild-type lenses, consistent with a failure of Tprm3-mutant lenses to osmoregulation. Ca(2+) homeostasis is recognized as having fundamental importance in lens pathophysiology was increased level of Ca2+ in human lenses with cortical cataract have been found to play a major role in the opacification process (ref. PMID: 19061888)
evidence.rdfs:label: Measuring Cation and Water Content of Trpm3-Mutant Lenses
